units.title: High‑resolution clustering and annotation
units.text: We clustered cells at high resolution in each dataset and assigned cell annotations based on known marker gene expression and differential expression between clusters (Supplementary Table 2).
units.rationale: Defines how cells were grouped and labeled.

units.title: Hierarchical cell‑type annotation via label‑aware integration
units.text: With label-aware integration, we established a three-level hierarchical cell-type annotation: class (level 1), type (level 2) and subtype (level 3) (Fig. 2a,b).
units.rationale: Creates a structured taxonomy for downstream analysis.

units.title: Assessment of data‑integration methods
units.text: We assessed 12 different data-integration methods using the proportion of cell types in each organoid sample and compared the similarity of each cell type with counterparts in adult and fetal tissues.
units.rationale: Evaluates which integration approach best preserves biological signals.

units.title: Selection of scPoli and generation of integrated embedding
units.text: selected scPoli20,22 to generate an integrated embedding of all orga- noid cells, enabling a cohesive representation of the diverse data (Fig. 1e and Extended Data Fig. 1e).
units.rationale: Chooses the optimal method to combine all datasets into a single space.

units.title: Reannotation of integrated atlas based on frequent cell type
units.text: The integrated atlas was reannotated based on the most frequent cell type in each cluster, resulting in 5 cell classes at level 1, 48 cell types at level 2 and 51 cell subtypes at level 3 (Fig. 1f–h and Extended Data Fig. 1f).

units.title: Reintegration and definition of multi‑level cell types
units.text: We reintegrated all cells and defined 5 cell types at level 1, 26 cell types at level 2 and 32 cell types at level 3 in the integrated atlas.
units.rationale: Creates a consistent cell‑type hierarchy across the full dataset.

units.title: Subsetting and reintegration of stem cells and enterocytes
units.text: We subsetted and reintegrated stem cells and enterocytes, and found that
units.rationale: Focuses on specific lineages for detailed comparison.

units.title: Pseudo‑bulk analysis using raw and scPoli embeddings
units.text: Pseudo-bulk analysis using both raw and scPoli embedding on all organoid single-cell datasets revealed stem cell source and tissue type as primary drivers of variance (Extended Data Fig. 4).
units.rationale: Identifies major sources of variation in the data.

units.title: Comparison with primary counterparts via neighborhood graph correlation
units.text: compared organoid cell types and states with primary counterparts using neighborhood graph correlation24.
units.rationale: Quantifies similarity between organoid and reference tissues.

units.title: Quantification of cell‑type proportions and similarity to reference
units.text: We quantified the proportion of cell types in each organoid sample and compared the similarity of each cell type with counterparts in adult and fetal tissues.
units.rationale: Measures how well organoid populations match in‑vivo references.
